pages.text: Shetland Sheepdogs have three genes that determine how they look. These are the B Locus, P Locus, and merle gene. The B Locus determines whether the dog has black or sable fur, while the P Locus only shows and black dogs and can create tan points. The merle gene determines if they show merle patterning or not.

The B Locus has two potential alleles, the dominant 'B' and the recessive 'b'. The 'B' allele creates black fur, while the 'b' allele creates sable fur. Dogs with one copy of 'b' will carry the red trait and may pass it on to pups, providing the potential for sable pups depending on the other parent. Dogs with two copies of 'b' will always create either sable carriers or sable puppies.
pages.title: B Locus

pages.text: The P Locus has two potential alleles, the dominant 'P' and the recessive 'p'. The 'P' allele does not affect the coat's color, while the 'p' allele creates tan points on the dog. Dogs with one copy of 'p' will carry the points trait and may pass it on to pups, providing the potential for point pups depending on the other parent. Dogs with two copies of 'p' will always create either point carriers or point puppies.
pages.title: P Locus

pages.text: Understanding of merle is limited, but from our understanding dogs will either be merle or they won't. Dogs that have the merle trait have a distinctive patchy look. Two merle parents will always produce a merle pup, while merle bred to a non-merle can produce a pup with or without the merle trait.
